resources.string: StoryBytes is a free and open-source Ink script reader. It is provided as-is under the MIT License. If you encounter any issues with the app, you\'re welcome to connect on the Github (https://github.com/micabytes/storybytes-android) or contact us on the MicaBytes discord server.

"StoryBytes" reads Ink Json files, generated by the inklecate run-time. If you have compiled Ink JSON files, you can simply place them in the StoryBytes directory on your internal storage. The app comes with two short json files pre-compiled.

To write your own stories, see the Ink documentation (https://github.com/inkle/ink) for a detailed overview. To make the simplest possible Ink script:
- Download the latest version inklecate from the Ink site.
- Create a text file MyStory.ink, containing the text "Hello, World!"
- On the command line, run "inklecate.exe MyStory.ink" (on Windows)
Copy MyStory.ink.json to the StoryBytes directory on your phone.
- Run the StoryBytes app and "play" your script.

Note that there is an excellent GUI editor for Ink (also developed by inkle), called Inky (https://github.com/inkle/inky). We recommend it highly, if you feel like creating bigger works.
\"StoryBytes\" is designed and developed by Michael Akinde of MicaBytes.

"StoryBytes" runs on Ink! Ink is a scripting language for writing interactive narrative, developed by inkle studios (https://inklestudios.com/ink).

The ink implementation used in "StoryBytes" is blade-ink (https://github.com/bladecoder/blade-ink) by Rafael Garcia (bladecoder).
Copy your own ink.json files into the StoryBytes directory to run them using the text player.
Press the play button to start the ink file.
